title: Verbum (Slovak magazine)
text:
Verbum was a <a href="Slovak%20language">Slovak language</a> <a href="magazine">magazine</a> focused primarily on writings of the <a href="Roman%20Catholic%20Church">Catholic</a> <a href="intelligentsia">intelligentsia</a>.
History and profile.
"Verbum" was founded in May 1946 at the parish in <a href="Liptovsk%C3%BD%20Hr%C3%A1dok">Liptovský Hrádok</a>, by the Catholic modernist poet <a href="Janko%20Silan">Janko Silan</a>. The Magazine took contributions from the whole spectrum of Catholic intellectuals, many of whom were previously editors of journals prior to <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. The most important contributors included:
In addition, the magazine also created a publishing house Verbum, in <a href="Ko%C5%A1ice">Košice</a>.
During its existence, the "Verbum" became very popular magazine, and could not manage to meet all orders. It had dedicated volumes that dealt with philosophy, art and one double issue was devoted to Protestantism. Verbum was instructed by <a href="communist">communist</a> officials to be destroyed in March 1948 (marked activity contributed Jozef Straka, among other things, arrest of Bishop John Vojtaššáka). Several contributors were arrested and spent many years in a communist prison.
